You can send the flow logs to an Azure Monitor Log Analytics workspace and then use Traffic Analytics to provide insights.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in.
Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol.
For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service.
Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the exposure of credential and secrets
countermeasure.desc:
When using a managed identity is not an option, ensure that secrets and credentials are stored in secure locations such as Azure Key Vault, instead of embedding them into the code and configuration files.
If you use Azure DevOps and GitHub for your code management platform: - Implement Azure DevOps Credential Scanner to identify credentials within the code. - For GitHub, use the native secret scanning feature to identify credentials or other forms of secrets within the code.
Clients such as Azure Functions, Azure Apps services, and VMs can use managed identities to access Azure Key Vault securely. See Data Protection controls related to the use of Azure Key Vault for secrets management.
Note: Azure Key Vault provides automatic rotation for supported services. For secrets which cannot be automatically rotated, ensure they are manually rotated periodically and purged when no longer in use.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure certificate management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control the certificate lifecycle, including the creation/import, rotation, revocation, storage, and purge of the certificate. Ensure the certificate generation follows the defined standard without using any insecure properties, such as insufficient key size, overly long validity period, insecure cryptography and so on. Setup automatic rotation of the certificate in Azure Key Vault and supported Azure services based on the defined schedule and when a certificate expires. If automatic rotation is not supported in the frontend application, use a manual rotation in Azure Key Vault.
Avoid using a self-signed certificate and wildcard certificate in your critical services due to the limited security assurance. Instead, you can create public signed certificates in Azure Key Vault. The following Certificate Authorities (CAs) are the partnered providers that are currently integrated with Azure Key Vault. - DigiCert: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with DigiCert. - GlobalSign: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with GlobalSign.
Note: Use only approved CA and ensure that known bad root/intermediate certificates issued by these CAs are disabled.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to management ports due to NSG misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to network resources or services, as well as potential exposure of open ports and network traffic to unauthorized entities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents may include malicious actors or unauthorized users attempting to gain access to network resources or services. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized attempts to connect to open ports from untrusted networks or intercepting and analyzing network traffic for sensitive information.
Impacts
The potential impacts include unauthorized access to network resources, exposure of sensitive data through intercepted network traffic, and potential exploitation of open ports for malicious purposes.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker from an untrusted network attempts to access the management ports of a service hosted on Azure, bypassing the network security group restrictions. Additionally, a malicious actor intercepts and analyzes network traffic to obtain sensitive information being transmitted between Azure resources due to the lack of private endpoints and Private Link features.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data exposure due to insecure certificate management and weak encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves the potential compromise of certificate lifecycle management and insecure data in transit encryption, leading to unauthorized access, data interception, and potential system compromise.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may exploit misconfigured certificate lifecycles, including insufficient key size, overly long validity period, or insecure cryptography. Attack vectors may include exploiting weak encryption, compromised key material, or interception of data in transit.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential system compromise, interception of data in transit, and exposure of sensitive information to unauthorized parties.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may intercept traffic between systems due to insecure data in transit encryption, leading to the compromise of sensitive information. Additionally, an attacker may exploit misconfigured certificate lifecycles, gaining unauthorized access and compromising system integrity.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to insecure storage of secrets and credentials
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing secrets and credentials in insecure locations, such as embedding them into code or configuration files, exposes sensitive information to potential unauthorized access and compromise.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users who may gain access to the code or configuration files. Attack vectors can involve unauthorized access to the code repository, code leaks, or configuration file exposures.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive information, potential data breaches, and compromise of system integrity, leading to reputation damage, financial loss, and regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the source code repository and extracts embedded secrets and credentials, leading to unauthorized access to critical systems and data. Another scenario involves a misconfiguration or accidental exposure of configuration files containing sensitive information, resulting in unauthorized access and potential exploitation by malicious actors.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized Azure resource configuration changes by malicious actors
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of misconfigured Azure resources poses a risk to the security and compliance of the cloud environment. Misconfigurations can lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and other security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious actors, internal employees, or third-party contractors. Attack vectors involve exploiting misconfigured security settings, access controls, or network configurations within Azure resources.
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigurations can lead to unauthorized access, data loss, service disruption, non-compliance, and potential financial and reputational damages to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages a misconfigured Azure storage account with public access enabled to exfiltrate sensitive data. Additionally, an internal employee mistakenly modifies network security group rules, allowing unauthorized access to resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Configure Azure Storage settings for each storage
countermeasure.desc:
To secure Azure Blob Storage settings and prevent unauthorized access, follow these steps:

  1. Enable Azure Active Directory (AAD) Authentication:
    1. Navigate to your Azure Storage account.
    2. In the left menu, select Access Control (IAM).
    3. Assign appropriate Azure roles for management and data access to users or service principals.
  2. Use Shared Access Signatures (SAS) with Caution:
    1. Generate SAS tokens with restricted permissions and a short expiration period.
    2. Monitor and audit the usage of SAS tokens to ensure they are being used as intended.
  3. Implement Network Security:
    1. Enable the Azure Storage Firewall to restrict network access.
    2. Add trusted IP ranges or virtual networks to control access to your storage account.
  4. Use Private Endpoints:
    1. Go to the Networking tab of your storage account.
    2. Select Private endpoint connections and configure a private endpoint connection within your virtual network.
  5. Ensure Data Encryption:
    1. Check if Server-Side Encryption with Microsoft-managed keys is enabled by default for your blobs.
    2. For additional control, use customer-managed keys, and store them in Azure Key Vault.
  6. Monitor and Alert:
    1. Implement Azure Monitor and set up alerts to track access logs and identify unusual activities.
    2. Enable diagnostic logging to capture data access and management events.

References

  • Azure Active Directory Authentication for Azure Storage
  • Using Shared Access Signatures (SAS)
  • Restrict network access to Azure Storage Accounts
  • Private Endpoints for Azure Storage
  • Azure Storage Encryption
  • Azure Monitor for Storage Accounts

countermeasure.name: Configure operational backup for Azure Blob Storage
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard your data against intentional or accidental deletion in Azure Blob Storage, it is crucial to establish a robust backup strategy. Follow these steps to set up operational backups:

  1. Identify Essential Data: Determine which Blob storage containers contain critical data that needs regular backups. This ensures efficient storage management and data recovery.
  2. Configure Azure Backup: Navigate to the Azure Portal and select the relevant Resource Group. Under the All services menu, go to Backup center under 'Monitor'.
  3. Create a Recovery Services Vault: Choose Vaults under 'Manage'. Click Add to create a new Recovery Services vault. Fill in the Name, Subscription, Resource group, and Region fields, and hit Create.
  4. Enable Soft Delete: This feature is pivotal for recovering deleted blobs. Go to your storage account, select Data protection under Blob service, and enable Soft delete for blobs.
  5. Set a Backup Policy: Within the Recovery Services vault, navigate to Backup policies and create a new policy. Set the frequency and retention settings that align with your organizations policies.
  6. Initiate Backups: Under the vaults dashboard, choose +Backup, select the storage account containing the blobs to backup, and apply the backup policy.
  7. Monitor Backups: Ensure successful backups by regularly checking the backup status in the Backup Jobs section of your Recovery Services vault.
  8. Test Recovery Process: Regularly perform test restores to validate the process and ensure you can swiftly recover data if necessary.

References

  • Azure Backup Overview
  • Azure Blob Storage Soft Delete
  • Azure Recovery Services Vault

countermeasure.name: Configure private endpoints for Azure Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing private endpoints for Azure Blob Storage ensures that only authorized users and applications access your storage account over secure, private network connectivity. Follow these steps to configure private endpoints:

  1. Create a Virtual Network (VNet):
    • Sign in to the Azure portal.
    • Navigate to 'Virtual networks' and click 'Create'.
    • Configure your VNet by specifying the subscription, resource group, and name.
    • Set the address space and subnet configurations suitable for your application needs.
    • Review and create the VNet.
  2. Set up the Private Endpoint:
    • With your VNet in place, go to 'Private link' and select 'Private endpoints'.
    • Click on 'Add' to create a new private endpoint.
    • Provide the necessary information including subscription, resource group, and name.
    • Select 'Target sub-resource type' as 'Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts', and choose your Blob Storage account.
    • In the networking tab, select your created VNet and a subnet within it.
    • Review the settings and click 'Create' to establish the private endpoint.
  3. Verify DNS Configuration:
    • Ensure that the DNS settings are configured to resolve the private endpoint connection.
    • If using Azure-provided DNS, verify that the private link will automatically handle DNS resolution.
    • For custom DNS solutions, configure A records to resolve to the private endpoint IP.
  4. Restrict Access via Network Rules:
    • Go to the Blob Storage account settings and access the 'Networking' section.
    • Update the network rules to allow access only from selected VNets and private endpoints.
    • Disable public access if not required to ensure tight security.
  5. Test the Private Endpoint Configuration:
    • Verify access by connecting to the Blob Storage from a resource within the VNet.
    • Check that no traffic is directed through public endpoints using network monitoring tools.

References

  • Azure Private Endpoint Overview
  • Plan and design Azure Virtual Networks
  • Create a storage account

countermeasure.name: Deploy network-based IDS/IPS
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of Azure Blob Storage, it is crucial to deploy network-based Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS) to monitor, detect, and block unauthorized network access attempts. Implementing IDS/IPS can significantly reduce the risk of breaches by providing real-time threat detection and automated response capabilities.

  1. Select an IDS/IPS Solution: Evaluate and choose an IDS/IPS that integrates smoothly with Azure environments. Consider solutions like Azure-native security tools or third-party options available through the Azure Marketplace.
  2. Integration with Azure Network: Set up the IDS/IPS within your Azure virtual network. Ensure that the IDS/IPS systems are configured to monitor all network traffic directed to Azure Blob Storage endpoints.
  3. Configuration: Configure the IDS/IPS to recognize patterns of unauthorized access, such as unusual access times, locations, and abnormal data retrieval rates. Fine-tune rules and policies to balance between detection and minimizing false positives.
  4. Deployment: Deploy the IDS/IPS using Azure Resource Manager templates or via Azure Portal interface. Ensure that all security settings comply with your organization's policies.
  5. Monitoring and Alerts: Establish a monitoring system and set up alerts for suspicious activities. Configure alert notifications to be sent to your security team via email, SMS, or integration with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) solutions.
  6. Regular Testing and Updates: Regularly test the IDS/IPS configurations to ensure they are effective against the latest threats. Keep the system updated with new threat signatures and software updates.
  7. Review and Reporting: Schedule regular reviews of IDS/IPS logs and generate reports to analyze network activity. Use this data to refine security policies and strategies.

References

  • Azure Network Watcher NSG Flow Logging
  • Azure Security Center
  • Azure Network Security Groups

countermeasure.name: Discover, classify, and label sensitive data for Azure Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing the utilization of Azure Storage capabilities to manage sensitive data involves several key steps to ensure data confidentiality and prevent unauthorized access. Follow the detailed steps below to effectively discover, classify, and label your sensitive data within Azure Blob Storage.

  1. Enable Azure Information Protection: Begin by enabling Azure Information Protection (AIP). This service allows for the classification, labeling, and protection of documents and emails across your organization.

    Access the Azure portal and navigate to Azure Active Directory > Azure Information Protection to activate the service.

  2. Configure Labels and Policies: Once Azure Information Protection is active, configure labels and policies that are suitable for your organizations data protection requirements.

    In the Azure portal, go to Azure Information Protection > Classifications > Labels and create labels for varying levels of data sensitivity.

  3. Implement Azure Blob Storage Management: Utilize features in Azure Blob Storage to work with the labels you've configured.

    Set up your Blob Storage container policies to automatically apply labels based on your defined criteria. Ensure proactive management of the stored data's classification and labeling through the Azure Storage Explorer or programmatically via the Azure SDKs.

  4. Deploy Azure Purview: Consider deploying Azure Purview to enhance your data governance strategy. Purview provides comprehensive data discovery and classification capabilities across your Azure Blob Storage and other Azure data services.

    Set up scans in Azure Purview to identify sensitive data types and automatically classify them according to your policies.

  5. Monitor and Audit Access: Implement regular monitoring and auditing mechanisms using Azure Monitor and Azure Security Center, ensuring only authorized personnel have access to sensitive data.

    Configure alerts to detect and respond to any unauthorized access attempts.

Maintaining continuous oversight and updating your policies as your data environment changes will support ongoing compliance and protection efforts against unauthorized access.

References

  • Azure Information Protection Overview
  • Azure Purview Overview
  • Azure Blob Storage Security Recommendations

countermeasure.name: Enable Azure Defender
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security monitoring and threat protection for Azure Blob Storage, leverage Azure Defender for Storage, providing a comprehensive solution that integrates seamlessly with Azure Security Center.

  1. Access Azure Security Center: Log in to the Azure portal and navigate to the Azure Security Center, where you can manage security for your resources.
  2. Enable Azure Defender for Storage: In the Azure Security Center, locate the 'Pricing & Settings' section. Select the subscription or resource hierarchy level where you want to enable Azure Defender.
  3. Select Storage Services: Scroll to find the 'Data Services' section and choose 'Storage' to enable Azure Defender for Blob Storage.
  4. Review Pricing and Enable Protection: Review the associated costs for Azure Defender for Storage, as it is billed separately from other Azure services. Click 'Save' to apply the changes and activate the protection.
  5. Configure Alerts and Policies: Access the 'Security Alerts' and 'Security Policy' settings to customize the detection capabilities, alert thresholds, and response actions according to your organizational security requirements.
  6. Monitor and Analyze Threats: Utilize the 'Threat Protection' and 'Alerts' sections within Azure Security Center to continuously monitor the health and security status of your Azure Blob Storage. Investigate and respond to any suspicious activities reported.
  7. Regularly Review and Update Settings: Periodically review your Azure Security Center settings, Azure Defender configurations, and ensure they align with cybersecurity best practices and organizational changes.

References

  • Azure Security Center Pricing

countermeasure.name: Enable NSG flow logs
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and auditing capabilities of Azure Blob Storage, it is crucial to activate Network Security Group (NSG) flow logs. This measure provides detailed logging of inbound and outbound network traffic, allowing for improved monitoring and detection of anomalies. Follow these steps to implement NSG flow logs:

  1. Navigate to the Azure Portal: Log into your Azure account and access the Azure portal by visiting Azure Portal.
  2. Locate the Network Security Group: Use the search bar to locate "Network Security Groups" and select the appropriate NSG associated with your Azure Blob Storage.
  3. Access NSG Flow Logs: Within the NSG pane, select "Diagnostics settings" located in the left-hand menu to configure logging options.
  4. Enable Diagnostics: Click on "Add diagnostic setting." Here, you can set up diagnostics for your NSG by specifying which logs and metrics you wish to capture, including Flow Logs.
  5. Choose a Storage Account or Event Hub: To store the log data, choose an Azure Storage account or stream it to an Azure Event Hub. For storage account, ensure that it complies with your data retention policies.
  6. Specify Retention Policies: Determine the retention period for the logs. This decision should reflect your compliance and audit requirements.
  7. Save Your Settings: After setting the desired configurations, click on "Save" to activate NSG Flow Logs. Flow data will start being generated based on your defined parameters.
  8. Verify Log Generation: After a short period, check the storage account or event hub to ensure logs are being captured as expected. This confirmation step is critical for ensuring that your logging setup is operational.

References

  • Network Security Group Flow Logging Overview
  • Configure NSG Flow Logging in the Azure Portal

countermeasure.name: Isolate Azure instances into different VNets
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and control over network access to your Azure Blob Storage, isolating Azure instances using Virtual Networks (VNets) is a highly effective strategy. This approach ensures that only authorized resources can connect to your storage accounts, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Below is a step-by-step guide to implement this control:

  1. Create a Virtual Network:

    • Navigate to the Azure portal.
    • On the left panel, select "Create a resource" and search for "Virtual Network."
    • Click "Create" to start the Virtual Network configuration.
    • Fill in the required fields such as Name, Address Space, and Subnet.
    • Select a subscription and resource group, then review and create the Virtual Network.

  2. Configure Network Security Group (NSG):

    • Navigate to the "Network Security Groups" section under All services.
    • Select "Create" and configure the NSG with the desired rules that control the inbound and outbound traffic.
    • Associate the NSG with the subnets in your Virtual Network for effective traffic filtering.

  3. Associate VNet with Azure Blob Storage:

    • In the Azure portal, go to your Blob Storage account.
    • Select "Networking" under the Settings section.
    • Choose "Private Endpoint connections" to associate your storage with the VNet.
    • Click "Add," select the Virtual Network, and configure the connection.
    • Approve the private endpoint connection to ensure restricted access to your storage account.

By following these steps, you isolate your Azure Blob Storage within a Virtual Network, ensuring that only specific network resources can access the storage, enhancing your data security.

References

  • Azure Virtual Network Overview
  • Manage a Network Security Group
  • Securing your storage account with Azure Virtual Network & firewalls

Enhancing security by configuring the Azure Storage Firewall to manage and restrict access to Azure Blob Storage involves setting up rules that dictate which IP addresses or ranges can access data. Follow these steps to implement the control:

countermeasure.name: Use managed identities
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing managed identities in Azure Blob Storage is a crucial step in enhancing security and controlling access to your data. Managed identities provide an automatically managed identity for applications to use when connecting to resources that support Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) authentication. They eliminate the need for developers to manage credentials, thereby reducing the risk of credential exposure or misuse.

  • Register your application with Azure AD:

Start by registering an application in Azure Active Directory. Navigate to Azure Active Directory App registrations New registration. Fill in the necessary details and complete the registration process.

  • Assign Managed Identity to the Application:

Go to the Azure portal and select the resource (like App Service, Virtual Machine) where you want to enable the managed identity. Under the "Settings" section, locate and select "Identity," then toggle the system-assigned managed identity to "On" and save the changes.

  • Assign Role to the Managed Identity in Azure Blob Storage:

Navigate to your Azure Blob Storage account. Under the "Access control (IAM)" section, select the "Add role assignment" option. Assign the necessary roles such as "Storage Blob Data Contributor" to the managed identity you just enabled, providing it with the appropriate permissions.

  • Authorize Access to the Blob Storage using Managed Identity:

In the application code, utilize Azure SDKs that support managed identities to authenticate and access Azure Blob Storage. Ensure the application configuration does not rely on stored credentials, but rather uses the identity to obtain an access token for the Azure resources.

  • Test Access Configuration:

Conduct thorough testing to confirm that the managed identity is properly set up and that the application can access Azure Blob Storage without using any hard-coded credentials. Correct any misconfigurations as needed.

Leveraging managed identities significantly enhances security by limiting unauthorized access and reducing the attack surface associated with handling credentials.

References

  • Azure Managed Identities Overview
  • Authenticate to Azure Blob Storage using Azure AD and managed identities
  • Role Assignments - Azure RBAC

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the control of the environment
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities in the system configuration or software to unlawfully access and control the Azure Blob Storage environment. This poses a risk of data exposure and other harmful actions that could compromise the integrity and security of the data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals or rogue insiders leveraging known or unknown software vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, or utilizing phishing techniques to gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
Breaches of confidential data, potential legal and regulatory consequences, loss of customer trust, financial losses, and operational disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured access control setting within the Azure Blob Storage and uses it to exfiltrate sensitive data. Alternatively, a phishing email dupes an employee into providing login credentials, allowing the attacker to log in and manipulate data containers.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system by exploiting weak security configurations
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers can take advantage of weak security configurations to access the Azure Blob Storage without proper authorization, potentially compromising sensitive data stored within it.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, including hackers, could exploit misconfigured settings or default credentials in the Blob Storage environment to gain entry. They may use automated tools to scan and identify such vulnerabilities quickly.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, exposure of confidential information, and potential legal and financial ramifications for the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
In one scenario, an attacker identifies publicly accessible blobs due to poor configuration, downloads sensitive files, and uses the data for financial gain or competitive advantage. In another case, the attacker finds a misconfigured storage account with default credentials, granting access to manipulate or delete critical business data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers perform unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to storage resources can lead to exposure or tampering with sensitive data within the cloud environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploiting vulnerabilities in network configurations or using compromised credentials to access cloud storage.
Impacts
A breach could result in data being stolen, corrupted, or deleted, risking the integrity and confidentiality of data, and potentially leading to financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a storage account using stolen credentials or through a network misconfiguration, subsequently exfiltrating sensitive data or altering configurations to disrupt operations.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data stored in the cloud storage service has the potential to be accessed and misused by unauthorized individuals, potentially leading to breaches in data privacy and harm to data integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers or malicious insiders could exploit misconfigured access policies, weak authentication methods, or vulnerabilities in the Blob Storage service to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information.
Impacts
The unauthorized access can result in data leaks or breaches, which might lead to financial losses, legal penalties, reputational damage, and compromise of customer trust or competitive advantage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might utilize phishing techniques to obtain legit access credentials from an employee, or a hacker may exploit a known service vulnerability to bypass authentication controls, leading to exposure or alteration of critical data stored within the cloud service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Exploitation of insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without effective logging and monitoring, unauthorized activities within Azure Blob Storage may go undetected, increasing the risk of exploitation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers, or compromised user credentials that exploit the lack of monitoring to perform illicit activities without being noticed.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and potential legal repercussions due to non-compliance with data protection regulations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a user's credentials and uploads malicious data to the Blob Storage, or accesses sensitive data without triggering any alerts due to absence of logging and monitoring mechanisms.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data is intentionally or accidentally deleted
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unintentional or intentional actions that lead to the deletion of data stored in Azure Blob Storage can pose a significant risk to information integrity and availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors with access to the storage system may intentionally delete data, while authorized personnel may accidentally delete data due to human error.
Impacts
Data loss which could lead to operational disruptions, financial losses, and damage to an organizations reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An employee mistakenly deleting critical data sets during a routine update; a disgruntled former employee accessing the system and intentionally deleting important data files.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in.
Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol.
For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service.
Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure certificate management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control the certificate lifecycle, including the creation/import, rotation, revocation, storage, and purge of the certificate. Ensure the certificate generation follows the defined standard without using any insecure properties, such as insufficient key size, overly long validity period, insecure cryptography and so on. Setup automatic rotation of the certificate in Azure Key Vault and supported Azure services based on the defined schedule and when a certificate expires. If automatic rotation is not supported in the frontend application, use a manual rotation in Azure Key Vault.
Avoid using a self-signed certificate and wildcard certificate in your critical services due to the limited security assurance. Instead, you can create public signed certificates in Azure Key Vault. The following Certificate Authorities (CAs) are the partnered providers that are currently integrated with Azure Key Vault. - DigiCert: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with DigiCert. - GlobalSign: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with GlobalSign.
Note: Use only approved CA and ensure that known bad root/intermediate certificates issued by these CAs are disabled.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data interception due to compromised certificates and insecure transfer protocols
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves the compromise of certificates and the use of insecure transfer protocols, potentially leading to unauthorized access, data interception, and impersonation attacks. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit weak certificate generation standards, automatic rotation misconfigurations, and the use of insecure transfer protocols to intercept sensitive data, gain unauthorized access, or impersonate legitimate entities. 
Impacts
The impact could include unauthorized access to sensitive data, interception of transmitted information, potential data manipulation, and impersonation of legitimate services or entities. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit weak certificate generation standards to obtain private keys and gain unauthorized access to sensitive information stored in Azure Key Vault. Additionally, the use of insecure transfer protocols could allow the attacker to intercept data transmitted between services, leading to potential data manipulation or unauthorized access. Furthermore, failure to enforce secure transfer protocols for remote management of Virtual Machines could lead to unauthorized access and compromise of critical systems.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized Azure resource configuration deviations detection and enforcement
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of misconfigurations in Azure resources poses a significant risk to the security and compliance of the cloud environment. Misconfigurations may lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, or service disruptions. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors, unauthorized users, or even accidental misconfigurations by legitimate users. Attack vectors could include improper access control settings, unencrypted data, or misconfigured network security rules. 
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigurations in Azure resources are diverse and could result in data exfiltration, service downtime, non-compliance penalties, or reputational damage. Unauthorized access, data loss, or service interruption are potential consequences. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a misconfiguration that allows public access to a storage account, leading to unauthorized data access or modification. Another scenario involves an unauthorized user exploiting a misconfigured network security group to gain unauthorized access to virtual machines.

weakness.name: CWE-1104
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1104: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components The product relies on third-party components that are not actively supported or maintained by the original developer or a trusted proxy for the original developer.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc: Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in. Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service. Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal. The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates. Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Perform vulnerability assessments
countermeasure.desc: Follow recommendations from Microsoft Defender for Cloud for performing vulnerability assessments on your Azure virtual machines, container images, and SQL servers. Microsoft Defender for Cloud has a built-in vulnerability scanner for virtual machines. Use a third-party solution for performing vulnerability assessments on network devices and applications (e.g., web applications) Export scan results at consistent intervals and compare the results with previous scans to verify that vulnerabilities have been remediated. When using vulnerability management recommendations suggested by Microsoft Defender for Cloud, you can pivot into the selected scan solution's portal to view historical scan data. When conducting remote scans, do not use a single, perpetual, administrative account. Consider implementing JIT (Just In Time) provisioning methodology for the scan account. Credentials for the scan account should be protected, monitored, and used only for vulnerability scanning. Note: Microsoft Defender services (including Defender for servers, containers, App Service, Database, and DNS) embed certain vulnerability assessment capabilities. The alerts generated from Azure Defender services should be monitored and reviewed together with the result from Microsoft Defender for Cloud vulnerability scanning tool. Note: Ensure you setup email notifications in Microsoft Defender for Cloud.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.

For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys. When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application. To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer. Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unscheduled or infrequent application backups leading to potential data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of data loss and downtime due to operational failure or security breaches is a concern with stateful applications, even if backup and recovery mechanisms are in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors seeking to disrupt or compromise the application and its data. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to the application and its storage, injection of malicious code, or intentional deletion or corruption of data.
Impacts
The impacts of a successful attack or operational failure could include loss of data, extended downtime, potential regulatory non-compliance, and damage to the organization's reputation and trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the application and its backup data, leading to the theft or deletion of critical information. 2. Malicious code injection results in the corruption or encryption of application data, rendering backups unusable for recovery. 3. Operational failure, such as misconfiguration or human error, causes accidental deletion or overwriting of critical data, leading to service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated or misconfigured anti-malware exposing Linux endpoints to advanced threats
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of outdated or improperly configured anti-malware solutions on Linux environments can result in increased vulnerability to malware and other cyber threats. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may exploit vulnerabilities in outdated anti-malware solutions, or bypass improperly configured solutions to deliver and execute malware on Linux systems. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include potential compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized access to systems, disruption of services, and exploitation of vulnerabilities for further attacks. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an outdated anti-malware solution on a Linux server, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data and compromising the integrity of the system. Alternatively, an attacker bypasses a misconfigured anti-malware solution to deliver and execute malware on a Linux endpoint, leading to further compromise and disruption of services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Unauthorized access to VMs due to improper RBAC management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to VM by former employees or unauthorized personnel can lead to data breaches, service disruption, or unauthorized data modification. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Former employees with revoked access, malicious insiders, or external attackers may attempt to gain access using compromised credentials, social engineering, or other unauthorized means. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access to the VM can lead to unauthorized data access, data exfiltration, service disruption, and potential modification of critical resources. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An ex-employee whose access was not properly revoked may still have access to the VM and can potentially exfiltrate sensitive data or disrupt services. A malicious insider could abuse their administrative privileges to access, modify, or delete critical data. External attackers might conduct credential stuffing attacks to gain unauthorized access to the VM.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized installation of Azure Monitor agent on virtual machines
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to sensitive data and systems in Azure virtual machines due to insufficient monitoring and protection measures. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit vulnerabilities in the virtual machines' operating systems or applications to gain unauthorized access. Attack vectors may include network-based attacks, malware injection, and exploitation of misconfigurations. 
Impacts
The impacts could range from unauthorized data access and exfiltration to disruption of services, data manipulation, and potential installation of backdoors for future attacks. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an unmonitored virtual machine, gaining access to sensitive data and deploying malware to evade detection by Defender for Servers and Azure Monitor. The attacker exfiltrates data or disrupts services without being noticed.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to unencrypted customer data
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to data at rest and in transit arises when encryption using customer-managed keys is not implemented, exposing sensitive information to potential compromise. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit weak or absent encryption controls, intercept data in transit through unsecured channels, gain unauthorized access to data at rest, or compromise encryption keys through unauthorized means. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data breaches, compromise of confidentiality and integrity, regulatory non-compliance, and reputational damage to the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted data transmitted over unsecured channels, such as HTTP, and extracts sensitive information from the communication. 2. A threat actor gains unauthorized access to unencrypted data at rest on virtual disks within Azure, potentially resulting in the exposure of sensitive information. 3. A malicious insider obtains unauthorized access to encryption keys, leading to the decryption of protected data and the compromise of confidentiality and integrity. 4. Attackers exploit legacy encryption protocols, such as SSL 3.0 or TLS v1.0, to exploit known vulnerabilities and gain access to sensitive data during transmission.

threat.name: Inadequate Network Security Group configuration for Azure VM Subnets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to network resources within the Azure environment can lead to a variety of security issues, including data breaches, service disruption, and unauthorized system manipulation. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can attempt to gain unauthorized access to network resources by exploiting misconfigured network security controls, performing port scanning to identify open ports, or attempting to bypass network filtering mechanisms. 
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to network resources can include data exfiltration, service disruption, unauthorized system manipulation, and potential compromise of sensitive information. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured Network Security Group (NSG) on a subnet within an Azure environment. The attacker exploits this misconfiguration to gain unauthorized access to open ports, allowing them to exfiltrate sensitive data or disrupt services within the network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access via embedded credentials and misconfigured Azure AD
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access and compromise of sensitive data arises when default authentication methods are not securely implemented, secrets and credentials are embedded in code or configuration files, and proper conditions and criteria for access control are not defined. Additionally, the use of service principals instead of managed identities can lead to unauthorized access and misuse of privileges. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit weak authentication methods, credentials embedded in code or configuration files, and lack of proper access controls. Attack vectors may include credential theft, unauthorized access from untrusted locations, and exploitation of service principal vulnerabilities. 
Impacts
The impacts of these threats include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, unauthorized modification or deletion of data, and potential compromise of the entire workload and infrastructure. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to code or configuration files containing embedded credentials, allowing them to impersonate legitimate users and access sensitive data. 

2. Malicious actors exploit weak authentication methods to gain unauthorized access to Azure resources and perform unauthorized actions within the workload. 

3. Attackers bypass conditional access policies and gain entry from untrusted or risky locations, potentially compromising data and resources. 

4. Threat actors exploit vulnerabilities in service principals to gain unauthorized access to Azure services and compromise the security of managed resources.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized application execution on VMs via Microsoft Defender and Azure Policy
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized applications running on virtual machines (VMs) can pose a threat to the security and stability of the environment. Without proper controls in place, malicious or unapproved applications could be executed, leading to potential exploitation of vulnerabilities or unauthorized access to sensitive data. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unintentional user actions. Attack vectors could involve exploiting vulnerabilities in applications, executing unauthorized scripts, or running unapproved software on the VMs. 
Impacts
The impact of unauthorized applications running on VMs can range from unauthorized access to sensitive information, introducing malware or viruses into the environment, disrupting the availability of services, or circumventing security controls. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a VM and installs a backdoor application that allows for persistent access and reconnaissance within the organization's network. Alternatively, an employee accidentally installs an unauthorized application that contains malware, leading to the compromise of the VM and potential spread to other resources in the environment.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to unpatched vulnerabilities and misconfigured Azure VMs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Implementing a control to maintain the security configuration of the operating system and ensuring the installation of security updates on Azure virtual machines is crucial to protect against threats targeting misconfigurations and known vulnerabilities in the cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors, automated bots, or insiders seeking to exploit misconfigurations, unpatched vulnerabilities, and insecure baseline configurations on Azure virtual machines. Attack vectors may involve direct exploitation through known vulnerabilities or indirect attacks leveraging weak security configurations. 
Impacts
The impacts of inadequate security configuration maintenance and patch management include unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of known security vulnerabilities to compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of Azure virtual machines and associated resources. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an unpatched Linux VM, gaining unauthorized access and exfiltrating sensitive data. Another scenario involves an insider making unauthorized changes to the security configuration of an Azure compute resource, leading to a security breach and potential exposure of critical assets to malicious actors.

weakness.name: CWE-1104
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1104: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components The product relies on third-party components that are not actively supported or maintained by the original developer or a trusted proxy for the original developer.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc: Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in. Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service. Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.desc: For Azure Backup supported resources (such as Azure VMs, SQL Server, HANA databases, Azure PostgreSQL Database, File Shares, Blobs or Disks), enable Azure Backup and configure the desired frequency and retention period. For Azure VM, you can use Azure Policy to have backup automatically enabled using Azure Policy. For example: - If you use Azure Storage for data storage, enable blob versioning for your storage blobs which will allow you to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Azure Storage. - Service configuration settings can usually be exported to Azure Resource Manager templates.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal. The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates. Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.
